Technological advancements and ever-changing work policies provide people with an option to work from home, rather than the office where they meet the team face to face. List out and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of working from home?

In present scenario, technology has changed and there is a lot of impact on humans every day life. As the time changes, people are opting for new techonoligal advancements. A new trend has started to work from home. The culture of work from home has come from foregin countries where it is encouraged and opted by many. This reduces stress and encourage many to work. This mainly encourage women to work and stand up on their own. Coaching classes has come online. Work from home also includes teaching online through coaching centers. The registered students can learn online at any time in their busy schedule. This helps students to learn their interested subjects with irrespective of their career. Employees of coaching centers will be experienced and talented to guide the students. These employees work from home and make money out of it. The projects given to the person who work from home may be on contractual basis or temporary or permanent projects.

Advantages of work from home are:

It saves time and reduces stress. Work from home mainly helps Women who cannot mange personal life and professional life can take up work from home. In present days traffic has become a  major issues in cities, People who work from home can get rid of this problems. Work from home helps organization to accomdate for less employees and more work can be done. It is the easy way to earn money in a limited period of time. Companies offering internships or temporary projects to work from home attracts many. Less work load and less pressure from superiors. Team work is less and individual work skills are seen. It is also helpful for students to learn their own interest other than their career. A good example for benefit out of online classes is, A Computer science student who is interested in robotics can learn online through coaching classes. 

 

Disadvantages of work from home:

Less interaction with people and do not gain much knowledge. A person need a physical exercise daily, whereas he do not get it if he works from home. No direct contact with superiors. It is the best way to earn money but not knowledge. Less guidence to the freshers and it doesn`t work in all fields. Trainning is not given to employees and does not result in fruitful outcome.

June 2013 - Auto Industry Outlook for Asia

Asia Promises High Growth

The Asian countries, especially China and India, are expected to account for 40% of growth in the auto industry over the next five to seven years being the rapidly growing economies.

Ford anticipates global sales to expand by 50% to 8 million vehicles by 2015 given the potential growth in Asia, mainly China and India; and rising demand for small cars. The automaker anticipates small cars to account for 55% of the total sales by 2020 compared with 48% presently. One third of the small car sales are expected to come from Asia.

In late 2012, Ford announced plans to boost exports of its engine production from India by shipping them for the first time to Europe. Currently, the automaker exports 40% of its Indian-made engines and 25% of its Indian-made cars to 35 countries. The company expects to manufacture 450,000 cars and 600,000 engines in India by 2015. It already pumped in $2 billion to build manufacturing facilities in India.

In April this year, General Motors revealed plans to build four new plants in China in order to boost annual production capacity to 5 million vehicles and triple its exports from Chinese plants by 2015. GM and its joint venture partners in China plan to invest $11 billion in the country by 2016 as part of their major expansion program.

In 2009, China overtook the U.S. as the biggest auto market in the world by sales volumes when the Beijing government introduced a stimulus package, including tax incentives for small cars. China accounted for a third of light vehicle sales growth in the last five years.

However, the incentives were scrapped in 2011 and the Beijing government imposed quotas on new car registrations in order to control the traffic congestions. In 2012, sales in China grew 4.3% to 19.3 million units, which is lower than the 8% growth projected by China Association of Automobile Manufacturers (CAAM) as well as the double-digit growth in 2009 and 2010.

Auto sales in the country are expected to improve if the government renews some of its policy incentives that helped the country overtake the U.S. as the biggest auto market. According to the Chinese government, total vehicle sales in China are expected to rise 7.8% to 20.8 million vehicles in 2013 from 19.3 million last year, led by strong demand for passenger vehicles and economic recovery. The CAAM believes SUVs will remain the fastest-growing segment in the year while commercial vehicles will record a moderate gain in sales.
